headline: Cintas Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is actually Greg calling on for Manav. First, I was just hoping if you could help us bridge to your 2017 revenues between what you would consider organic growth and the FX or M&A impact? And maybe more specifically, if you can talk about how you're t
componenttext: This is actually Greg calling on for Manav. First, I was just hoping if you could help us bridge to your 2017 revenues between what you would consider organic growth and the FX or M&A impact? And maybe more specifically, if you can talk about how you're thinking about organic growth in 2017 and how it compares to the, I guess, nearly 7% you delivered in 2016?

headline: Cintas Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Greg, we don't typically give organic growth because lots of things can happen throughout the year. But I -- you can probably see from our guidance, where the revenue ranges 5% to 6.5%, that's pretty much in line with what we gave in terms of initial guid
componenttext: Greg, we don't typically give organic growth because lots of things can happen throughout the year. But I -- you can probably see from our guidance, where the revenue ranges 5% to 6.5%, that's pretty much in line with what we gave in terms of initial guidance last year. Keep in mind that, as I mentioned, we'll get a negative impact of 40 to 50 basis points because of the one less workday. And so I would say that we are not expecting too many changes this year. But we don't give specific organic growth numbers.

headline: Cintas Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, fair enough. And then maybe on the energy side. It sounded like the negative net add-stops were a little worse than you'd expected in the fourth quarter. Maybe you can talk about the moving pieces and how you're thinking about that in 2017 between n
componenttext: Okay, fair enough. And then maybe on the energy side. It sounded like the negative net add-stops were a little worse than you'd expected in the fourth quarter. Maybe you can talk about the moving pieces and how you're thinking about that in 2017 between new cost saves and potential further pressures, if we're in a lower for longer oil environment?

headline: Cintas Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Greg, it's Paul. Add-stops were -- they were negative this quarter. But they typically are. There are some seasonal impacts that impact us in the fourth quarter. For example, we have jackets coming off from the winter and being returned to the stock
componenttext: Yes, Greg, it's Paul. Add-stops were -- they were negative this quarter. But they typically are. There are some seasonal impacts that impact us in the fourth quarter. For example, we have jackets coming off from the winter and being returned to the stock rooms. We have mats that are extra mats that some of the customers were snow and slush and those are returned as well. So typically, add-stops are negative in the fourth quarter and they are for us this fourth quarter. And then to your point, they are a little more so than typical because we still are feeling the effects of headcount reductions in our energy customers. In terms of next fiscal year, we can tell you that we still expect to have some headwinds from oil, gas and coal customers. We would expect the headwind to revenue in fiscal '17 to about 60 basis points and that's built into our guidance. So at the top line impact on the bottom line, we would expect that to be a headwind then of about 30 basis points of operating margin. The other impact that we believe we will have is just in the fuel costs whereas we had a benefit in fiscal '16, we're modeling that the fuel will be a headwind to our cost structure to maybe about 30 basis points.

headline: Cintas Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: A headwind to -- on the cost side? So higher fuel cost?
componenttext: A headwind to -- on the cost side? So higher fuel cost?

headline: Cintas Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. On fiscal '16, on a net benefit -- or a net basis rather, on fiscal '16, considering the benefit of fuel and the cost structure and then the negative impact of the headcount reductions, reducing revenue and operating margin, we had, like, a 10 basis
componenttext: Yes. On fiscal '16, on a net benefit -- or a net basis rather, on fiscal '16, considering the benefit of fuel and the cost structure and then the negative impact of the headcount reductions, reducing revenue and operating margin, we had, like, a 10 basis point improvement for fiscal '16. Whereas in fiscal '17, we're expecting it to be more of a 60 basis points headwind. So quite a significant change.

headline: Cintas Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll take our next question from Gary Bisbee with RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: We'll take our next question from Gary Bisbee with RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Cintas Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: I thought it was an interesting statistic you gave. If I heard it right, that 70% of your revenue you think is from services industry end markets or customers. And can you just help us frame that? I mean, how -- what would that have looked like 5 years ag
componenttext: I thought it was an interesting statistic you gave. If I heard it right, that 70% of your revenue you think is from services industry end markets or customers. And can you just help us frame that? I mean, how -- what would that have looked like 5 years ago? Has that been a pretty substantial shift over time? Or has it been more moderate?

headline: Cintas Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would say, in the last 5 years, probably not too substantial. But over the last, let's call it, 15 years, probably much more, probably even more inverse of that. As jobs, over the last couple of decades, have been offshore, we've certainly been forced t
componenttext: I would say, in the last 5 years, probably not too substantial. But over the last, let's call it, 15 years, probably much more, probably even more inverse of that. As jobs, over the last couple of decades, have been offshore, we've certainly been forced to look for other ways of creating revenue in terms of the uniforms. And that, we've been very successful in the service providing area. And so I would say it's different from certainly 15 years ago. It's probably not too different from 5 years ago. But I would say that it continues -- we continue to perform well in those areas. A couple of the different pieces that we would see as better today than maybe 5 years ago even, and certainly, '15 [ph] will be healthcare, which, 15 years ago, we probably had a very, very small presence in food service. And in both of those, we've been able to come up with creative solutions, innovative solutions to get more of an impact on those verticals. And that certainly has helped us.

headline: Cintas Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: And when we think about that, is that both a uniform rental story? And then also just penetration of a lot of the other stuff that has broader appeal? Or is it more the latter than the former?
componenttext: And when we think about that, is that both a uniform rental story? And then also just penetration of a lot of the other stuff that has broader appeal? Or is it more the latter than the former?

headline: Cintas Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. That's all of our businesses. And when you think about the rental segments by itself, there's not a lot of difference in terms of the vertical splits between Uniform Rental and Facility Services. We are providing many of those products to the same cus
componenttext: No. That's all of our businesses. And when you think about the rental segments by itself, there's not a lot of difference in terms of the vertical splits between Uniform Rental and Facility Services. We are providing many of those products to the same customers. So not a lot of difference there.

headline: Cintas Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And then if I could just ask one more. Can you give us any more color on how the branding campaign is working? I think we saw, we've seen the commercials and seen them on the Internet, a few other things. But what has that done? Is that just
componenttext: Okay, great. And then if I could just ask one more. Can you give us any more color on how the branding campaign is working? I think we saw, we've seen the commercials and seen them on the Internet, a few other things. But what has that done? Is that just awareness? Or are you actually seeing this help you close the business? Thank you.

headline: Cintas Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, the branding campaign has continued and we certainly -- our Cintas partners, our employees, are very energized and excited about it. And so it's had a positive impact on us, certainly, from an energy and excited standpoint. But we're too early to be
componenttext: Well, the branding campaign has continued and we certainly -- our Cintas partners, our employees, are very energized and excited about it. And so it's had a positive impact on us, certainly, from an energy and excited standpoint. But we're too early to begin the measure of the impact of it. I think I mentioned last quarter that it would probably more like the second half of fiscal '17 before we would start to really be able to measure any kind of impact. Keeping in mind, it is a brand awareness campaign. So it is trying to make sure that our customers and our prospects understand and know all of the different things that we can provide to them, all of the different products and services. And we're not specifically targeting any one of them right now. So again, we're excited about it. It's going well. It's been -- the feedback that we get anecdotally has been very good. But I don't expect to be able to give any measurements on it until the back half of fiscal '17.

headline: Cintas Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll take our next question from Nate Brochmann with William Blair.
componenttext: We'll take our next question from Nate Brochmann with William Blair.

headline: Cintas Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: So just playing off at Gary's question there a little bit, and I think that's one thing that you guys have really done a great job of in terms of maintaining the sales momentum and somewhat of an underlying sluggish job growth environment. Could you talk
componenttext: So just playing off at Gary's question there a little bit, and I think that's one thing that you guys have really done a great job of in terms of maintaining the sales momentum and somewhat of an underlying sluggish job growth environment. Could you talk a little bit about, as you go back 15 years ago till today, in terms of being able to change the customer buying behavior to kind of except maybe those new rental uniforms that you have going into those newer industries for you? And then second, how much longer is that tailwind in terms of opportunity given the fact that it's been only in last, call it, 5 or 7 years that we've really made some real inroads there?

headline: Cintas Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think the -- from a customer perspective, I think it begins with innovative products. We can't get service industry to just simply change with what we might call legacy, uniform rental workwear. We have to be innovative. And we have to create unif
componenttext: Well, I think the -- from a customer perspective, I think it begins with innovative products. We can't get service industry to just simply change with what we might call legacy, uniform rental workwear. We have to be innovative. And we have to create uniform solutions that our customers want to wear. And we think we've been pretty successful in doing that. Paul gave a couple of examples in his narrative a few minutes ago. And so it really starts with innovative products and solutions. And we feel like that's -- we've been pretty good at that. That's going to be important, to continue to do that as we move forward. As far as how much opportunity is still out there, we feel like there is quite a bit of opportunity. We continued to introduce new products like our Carhartt, like our Scrub Rental, like our ChefWorks products for rental. And it takes a while to get those fully penetrated and fully rolled out. And so there's a lot of runway in just our existing products and that doesn't include any products that we will continue to invest in and look for.

headline: Cintas Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: And I assume along with that, though, like the word of mouth, in terms of people within the industry, you've been talking, that's kind of help accelerate that runway little bit, right?
componenttext: And I assume along with that, though, like the word of mouth, in terms of people within the industry, you've been talking, that's kind of help accelerate that runway little bit, right?

headline: Cintas Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I would say that the more prospecting we do and the more that we talk about our solutions, yes, the better that can become. And that, from a word-of-mouth standpoint, that gets around to different decision-makers.
componenttext: Well, I would say that the more prospecting we do and the more that we talk about our solutions, yes, the better that can become. And that, from a word-of-mouth standpoint, that gets around to different decision-makers.

headline: Cintas Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then second question is when you originally announced some of the upfront costs related to SAP, I think there might have been a little bit of an initial worry about what we can do to offset that, I mean, clearly, with your guidance going into ne
componenttext: Okay. And then second question is when you originally announced some of the upfront costs related to SAP, I think there might have been a little bit of an initial worry about what we can do to offset that, I mean, clearly, with your guidance going into next year, that's pretty strong. I would assume that you have uncovered some offsets to kind of help balance some of those costs. And obviously, you're really great in terms of the gross margin expansion as well. Could you talk about maybe some of those things underneath the covers that you're able to find to offset that, particularly given some of the headwinds that you are facing in terms of the lost day and the energy cost, et cetera?

headline: Cintas Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. I would say, Nate, it's not that we've uncovered a lot of different things. It's just that -- I'll go through a couple of things. We won't have the incremental IT investments that we would typically have, and that's helpful. We expect certainly impr
componenttext: Sure. I would say, Nate, it's not that we've uncovered a lot of different things. It's just that -- I'll go through a couple of things. We won't have the incremental IT investments that we would typically have, and that's helpful. We expect certainly improved performance out of our First Aid and Safety business as we lapped the acquisition of ZEE. Again, we expect to see improved performance, certainly. And we expect to see improved performance out of our Fire business. Those certainly will help. And you're seeing that as part of the guidance. We will certainly get some natural leverage from the growth in our rental segment and that will help. And then, we're also continuing to control our costs and manage our cost structure. And we've been pretty successful at that and we'll continue to be successful at that. So there are a number of different things that go into helping us and help offset some of the headwinds that we've talked about. But I think -- there's nothing, there's no magic silver bullet that we've got that we've all of a sudden uncovered. It's continuing to do what we do.

headline: Cintas Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll take our next question from Sara Gubins with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: We'll take our next question from Sara Gubins with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: Cintas Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just to follow up on that. At the end of your last comment, you said that overall, you're focused on managing the cost structure. Could you add in a little bit more detail about where, aside for natural leverage in the business, you're able to do that?
componenttext: Just to follow up on that. At the end of your last comment, you said that overall, you're focused on managing the cost structure. Could you add in a little bit more detail about where, aside for natural leverage in the business, you're able to do that?

headline: Cintas Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, aside from investments that we choose to make, our expectation is that we're going to grow our G&A about half as much as revenue each year. And we've been pretty good at that, again, aside from certain investments that we want to make. And so, a lot
componenttext: Well, aside from investments that we choose to make, our expectation is that we're going to grow our G&A about half as much as revenue each year. And we've been pretty good at that, again, aside from certain investments that we want to make. And so, a lot of it comes from managing that G&A structure. A lot of it comes from an active Six Sigma program where we are constantly looking for small incremental wins to medium-sized wins. And those Six Sigma process improvements come in our production, in our plants, they come on our routes, they come in all different places. We have a lot of people who are involved in that Six Sigma program, looking for small and medium-sized wins. And that will certainly help as we become more and more efficient in all of our processes.

headline: Cintas Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016

componenttextpreview: Sara, it's Paul. Yes, on the pricing front, we haven't really seen anything in terms of the marketable change. So it's -- we've been pretty status quo. Still competitive in terms of National Account programs, but that hasn't changed and really no differen
componenttext: Sara, it's Paul. Yes, on the pricing front, we haven't really seen anything in terms of the marketable change. So it's -- we've been pretty status quo. Still competitive in terms of National Account programs, but that hasn't changed and really no difference. So nothing noteworthy or anything significant to pass on to you there.

headline: Cintas Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And just last question, could you talk about your priorities for capital next year?
componenttext: Okay, great. And just last question, could you talk about your priorities for capital next year?

headline: Cintas Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, Sara, I would say that those priorities are -- will be the same as they have been for fiscal '16. I talked a little bit about that in our prepared remarks. We're going to continue to invest in the business. We're going to continue to do that through
componenttext: Well, Sara, I would say that those priorities are -- will be the same as they have been for fiscal '16. I talked a little bit about that in our prepared remarks. We're going to continue to invest in the business. We're going to continue to do that through the -- a little bit of the P&L but also through CapEx. We are certainly going to be looking for acquisition opportunities that create long-term value for us similar to the way we did that in fiscal '16. Our third priority is we will take a look at the dividend. And if history repeats, we will likely increase the dividend this year because that has been very important to us. And then lastly, if there are -- if there is cash remaining, we certainly will put it to work in share buybacks. But we will look at it in that priority order and making sure that we are always looking to strengthen Cintas for the long-term.

headline: Cintas Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll take our next question from Jeff Goldstein with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: We'll take our next question from Jeff Goldstein with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Cintas Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: I want to ask about the All Other segment. Where it looks like you've had some strong growth in the quarter. First of all, are you able to provide the organic growth for that segment? And then secondly, was growth there driven by any large one-off orders
componenttext: I want to ask about the All Other segment. Where it looks like you've had some strong growth in the quarter. First of all, are you able to provide the organic growth for that segment? And then secondly, was growth there driven by any large one-off orders in Direct Sales? Or is it more broad-based in nature?

headline: Cintas Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I can provide you with the organic growth of All Other, it was 8.5% in the quarter. And that All Other, just as a reminder, includes our Fire business and our Direct Sale business. And that Direct Sale business is typically more of a slower grower in
componenttext: Yes, I can provide you with the organic growth of All Other, it was 8.5% in the quarter. And that All Other, just as a reminder, includes our Fire business and our Direct Sale business. And that Direct Sale business is typically more of a slower grower in our portfolio. But it had a good quarter. It was a little stronger growth rate. Again, that's Direct Sale business, it can be a little more volatile. So we had some good rollouts of programs in the fourth quarter that helped push growth along and get that organic growth rate up pretty nicely. The Fire business continues to grow nicely as well. We expect about double-digit growth in our Fire business. And so as a result of growing the top line in both of those businesses, we also saw 100 basis points of operating margin expansion in that segment as well.

headline: Cintas Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then I want to ask about cotton prices, which have actually increased pretty significantly recently. Would you expect any type of headwinds to your business if you're able to see kind of more of a sustained period of these higher cotton prices?
componenttext: Okay. And then I want to ask about cotton prices, which have actually increased pretty significantly recently. Would you expect any type of headwinds to your business if you're able to see kind of more of a sustained period of these higher cotton prices?

headline: Cintas Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, cotton, we would have to see a sustained increase in cotton and for a while. So let's talk about, specifically, for our rental business. When we think about most of our uniforms, they are polycotton blend or lower percentage of cotton. So that is --
componenttext: Well, cotton, we would have to see a sustained increase in cotton and for a while. So let's talk about, specifically, for our rental business. When we think about most of our uniforms, they are polycotton blend or lower percentage of cotton. So that is -- that's point number 1. Secondly, labor is the biggest component of cost out of our garments. And so these materials are not the majority of the cost involved. Thirdly, there is a supply chain. So we will -- we would have to order the fabric. It would be sewn into garments. That -- and then shipped to our distribution center. That probably takes somewhere of 8 to 10 weeks. Then there's a turn through the distribution center and then it gets shipped out to our rental locations where it gets generally amortized over some period of time, mostly 18 months. So there's quite a bit of time before we would see a sustained cotton impact. And even if we did see a sustained cotton impact, because of the percentage of the cost itself, I don't see that -- I just don't expect that that would be that noticeable and it would have to be a real spike for some sustained period of time.

headline: Cintas Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful. And then I just have one last maintenance question. You had said that regarding the national advertising campaign that spending on the campaign would likely ramp up again in fiscal '17. Is that still the guidance? And do you have any
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. And then I just have one last maintenance question. You had said that regarding the national advertising campaign that spending on the campaign would likely ramp up again in fiscal '17. Is that still the guidance? And do you have any color on which quarters would likely see more of that spend?

headline: Cintas Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: At -- we expect that our spend will be about the same in fiscal '17 as fiscal '16, which, for the year, is about 25 basis points. I would expect that the largest -- or the impact would be the greatest in our second and third quarters.
componenttext: At -- we expect that our spend will be about the same in fiscal '17 as fiscal '16, which, for the year, is about 25 basis points. I would expect that the largest -- or the impact would be the greatest in our second and third quarters.

headline: Cintas Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll take our next question from Andrew Whitman with R.W. Baird.
componenttext: We'll take our next question from Andrew Whitman with R.W. Baird.

headline: Cintas Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. So Mike, thanks for the answer previously about some of the offsets that you had through the margins. Given that those headwinds are pretty significant, I was wondering if you can give us a little bit more detail. And in the past, you mentioned tha
componenttext: Great. So Mike, thanks for the answer previously about some of the offsets that you had through the margins. Given that those headwinds are pretty significant, I was wondering if you can give us a little bit more detail. And in the past, you mentioned that the ZEE integration, that you thought that the segment margins could get back up to the pre-ZEE levels, which I guess is, I don't know, 13-ish percent for the segment? Is that still the right goal? And what's the timeframe to which you think you can get those ZEE margins? Or to get these significant offsets, are you now eyeing above prior segment margin peaks?

headline: Cintas Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Andy, it's Paul. Yes, as far as ZEE is concerned, I just want to reiterate that we are pleased with that acquisition. Everything is on track. We had mentioned previously that we need a full year to get through the integration. And so through May, we're ab
componenttext: Andy, it's Paul. Yes, as far as ZEE is concerned, I just want to reiterate that we are pleased with that acquisition. Everything is on track. We had mentioned previously that we need a full year to get through the integration. And so through May, we're about 75% of the way through. It's not turnkey. It's not standalone as you know. It's largely a tuck-in. And so when you have a tuck-in, you have a low [ph] short term, short-term efforts in order to get those synergies in the long-term. And that's definitely what were seeing in the First Aid segment as that impact the integration costs, rerouting, good will in customers to make sure nothing falls through in the transition. You can't run as fast as you would like to right out of the gate. But things are on track. We do expect gross margins to bounce back. We don't have a timeframe as far as, here's the timetable and the quarters and the milestones. But absolutely, we have another quarter of integration in fiscal '17 and we expect to see those margins bounce back and baked into our guidance for fiscal '17 as improvements in those First Aid and Safety margins and some stronger growth rates that you saw in the fourth quarter as well.

headline: Cintas Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Andy, I would add to that, from a Fire Protection Services perspective, we continue to grow that business and we grow it -- we've grown it quite nicely in the last year. Paul talked about it growing nicely in the fourth quarter. And we expect continued op
componenttext: Andy, I would add to that, from a Fire Protection Services perspective, we continue to grow that business and we grow it -- we've grown it quite nicely in the last year. Paul talked about it growing nicely in the fourth quarter. And we expect continued operating margin improvement in that business as well as we gain density in a lot of our different markets. And as that business continues to do the same thing that our other businesses do, and that is fine product adjacencies, continue to penetrate existing customers while adding new storefronts. Our National Account fire business has been very good over the last year as well. And so there, we expect, certainly, improvements in the First Aid business, as Paul talked about. But we also expect them in our Fire Protection business. And that certainly will help us in fiscal '17.

headline: Cintas Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, thank you for that context. On the capital budget, I think I heard $280 million to $320 million that compares to $275 million-ish this year. I'm just curious as -- we -- I think we had decent SAP spending in fiscal '16. I think I heard you say that
componenttext: Okay, thank you for that context. On the capital budget, I think I heard $280 million to $320 million that compares to $275 million-ish this year. I'm just curious as -- we -- I think we had decent SAP spending in fiscal '16. I think I heard you say that there is $40 million expected in fiscal '17. But I still think that's a pretty decent increase and I was wondering what do you contribute the delta to?

headline: Cintas Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we will be adding capacity like we talked about. I believe we'll have a couple of different facilities open here early in this fiscal year. Those were not full newbuilds but they were capacity increases. And that will give us some help in the first
componenttext: Well, we will be adding capacity like we talked about. I believe we'll have a couple of different facilities open here early in this fiscal year. Those were not full newbuilds but they were capacity increases. And that will give us some help in the first quarter. And then we expect to continue to increase capacity because of our growth, probably closer to the end of the fiscal year or into early fiscal '18. So there's a little bit more capacity spend than we've seen over the last, certainly, over the last 3 to 5 years and even a little bit more than we've seen in fiscal '16.

headline: Cintas Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, last question. It's been reported that you guys are going to -- you've had, I think the Southwest Airlines contract for a while which, correct me if I'm wrong, was mostly a Direct Sale. Last time you guys redressed an airlines, I think it was United
componenttext: Okay, last question. It's been reported that you guys are going to -- you've had, I think the Southwest Airlines contract for a while which, correct me if I'm wrong, was mostly a Direct Sale. Last time you guys redressed an airlines, I think it was United Airlines and that was a tangible number that we could see through the P&L. Is the Southwest Airlines on the same order of magnitude in terms of the contribution? And how should we expect the timing of that to flow through? And maybe any comments you'd have on the profitability? Has that brought a major program, and I think it would be a fairly short order.

headline: Cintas Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: That is a great success for us in terms of gaining the award for that business. That's -- of the impactful piece of that is relatively new. It's early, so I'm not ready to provide any timetable and estimates. But we'll certainly talk more about that as we
componenttext: That is a great success for us in terms of gaining the award for that business. That's -- of the impactful piece of that is relatively new. It's early, so I'm not ready to provide any timetable and estimates. But we'll certainly talk more about that as we go through the performance of that business. But we're early on. Again, we've got to source the product and that takes time. So those big projects don't happen overnight. In fact, I think we started working on the United program, something like 12 to 15 months in advance of starting to ship. So it's -- it is a nice program for us. But it's going to take a little time.

headline: Cintas Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, so the implication there, is if United was 12 plus months, this one might not even have a lot of revenue contribution this year? Is that fair to say?
componenttext: Okay, so the implication there, is if United was 12 plus months, this one might not even have a lot of revenue contribution this year? Is that fair to say?

headline: Cintas Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016

componenttext: I think that's a fair assumption.

headline: Cintas Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016

componenttext: We'll take our next question from Joe Box with KeyBanc.

headline: Cintas Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: So couple of questions around the Uniform segment organic growth rate. One, is the growth rate for Uniform versus All Other kind of categories within that Uniform segment? Are you still seeing the growths kind of trended a similar rate or are you starting
componenttext: So couple of questions around the Uniform segment organic growth rate. One, is the growth rate for Uniform versus All Other kind of categories within that Uniform segment? Are you still seeing the growths kind of trended a similar rate or are you starting to see them to diverge? And two, if I heard you right, it sounded like you highlighted new business wins, better penetration and even retention as kind of the biggest drivers to the entire segment. I'm curious if any of those three things are either accelerating or decelerating?

headline: Cintas Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I would say that the fiscal '16, as we've talked a lot about, had an impact on, from our oil, gas and mining customers, throughout the year. And that has had a bit of a negative impact on the growth of the Uniform side relative to the whole segment.
componenttext: Well, I would say that the fiscal '16, as we've talked a lot about, had an impact on, from our oil, gas and mining customers, throughout the year. And that has had a bit of a negative impact on the growth of the Uniform side relative to the whole segment. So it is a little bit -- the Uniform Rental side is a little bit lower in terms of the growth than the average. And we've been able to pick that up through the Facility Services, both in new business and in the penetration. And as Paul said, the retention. I would say that from the standpoint of do any one of those three stick out dramatically? I would say, no. But I would say, that the penetration, we have lots of opportunity left. There is lots of runway to continue to add value to our existing customers. And we've been very successful with that in fiscal '16, particularly with some of our hygiene products and services like our Signature Series, kind of a more front of the house hygiene business. And I think what I am describing kind of shows itself in the numbers that Paul gave, and that is that the Uniform Rental business was 51% of that revenue last year, it's now 50%. The hygiene was 13% last year, it's now 14%. That's what you're seeing. You're seeing some lost oil, gas and mining customers, but it's being offset by some nice penetration and improvements in retention.

headline: Cintas Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. Appreciate that. And then maybe switching gears to the SAP side. Can you talk -- I know, obviously, it's very early in the Uniform Rental side. But can you maybe just talk about the number of branches that you've rolled out maybe through mid-July a
componenttext: Right. Appreciate that. And then maybe switching gears to the SAP side. Can you talk -- I know, obviously, it's very early in the Uniform Rental side. But can you maybe just talk about the number of branches that you've rolled out maybe through mid-July and some early impressions or challenges that you might have had with that?

headline: Cintas Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we just recently started our pilot. And early indications are that we're off to a very good start. However, we're early. I think I talked about this last quarter. Our pilot is effectively starting with one location and really learning a lot. And ass
componenttext: Well, we just recently started our pilot. And early indications are that we're off to a very good start. However, we're early. I think I talked about this last quarter. Our pilot is effectively starting with one location and really learning a lot. And assuming that goes well, we will move to several others. So that by the -- by mid fiscal year, our expectation would be that we're kind of ready to start rolling out full speed. So right now, we're in that early pilot stage with one location. And like I said, early indications are it's going pretty well. But again, we're early and I think we'll have more to say about that more than likely at the end of our first and second quarters.

headline: Cintas Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And maybe I guess in that same vein, clearly, SAP is going to be a big project for you guys over the next couple of years. Your balance sheet is generally under levered. I'm curious if you guys would be willing to do a sizable deal throughout this
componenttext: Got it. And maybe I guess in that same vein, clearly, SAP is going to be a big project for you guys over the next couple of years. Your balance sheet is generally under levered. I'm curious if you guys would be willing to do a sizable deal throughout this SAP process? Or would you pretty much table any sort of major deal until the SAP was completely rolled out?

headline: Cintas Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I would tell you that this SAP is a big project. And we've got a lot of resources and attention put to that. But opportunities don't come along everyday. And if we had an opportunity, small or large to add value for the long-term benefit of Cintas,
componenttext: Well, I would tell you that this SAP is a big project. And we've got a lot of resources and attention put to that. But opportunities don't come along everyday. And if we had an opportunity, small or large to add value for the long-term benefit of Cintas, we certainly would take a look at it. And again, at the right value, we would certainly love to do M&A that provides long-term value. That is the same message that we've had for quite a while and that doesn't change during the SAP rollout. It certainly may affect the way we would integrate it. But if we have opportunities that create great value for Cintas, we'll still take a good look at it.

headline: Cintas Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll take our next question from Scott Schneeberger with Oppenheimer.
componenttext: We'll take our next question from Scott Schneeberger with Oppenheimer.

headline: Cintas Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: From the press release, we know that -- and typically, you guys anticipate a fairly flat economy in the forward guidance. Could you speak to how you think about employment maybe with regard to oil and gas and mining? And then ex-ing that out, how do you t
componenttext: From the press release, we know that -- and typically, you guys anticipate a fairly flat economy in the forward guidance. Could you speak to how you think about employment maybe with regard to oil and gas and mining? And then ex-ing that out, how do you think about it? Thanks.

headline: Cintas Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we've -- from an oil, gas and mining standpoint, we have seen continued deterioration. But I would say, today, that rate of deterioration is slowing, certainly, relative to 90 days ago. But as Paul mentioned, we still expect to see a negative 60 bas
componenttext: Well, we've -- from an oil, gas and mining standpoint, we have seen continued deterioration. But I would say, today, that rate of deterioration is slowing, certainly, relative to 90 days ago. But as Paul mentioned, we still expect to see a negative 60 basis points to the top line. So that tells you that we don't -- we won't feel healed in that area in fiscal '17. From the rest of the, let's call it, economic picture, I would say that it's still a challenging environment. There's not a lot of momentum to it. But I would call it stable. We haven't seen a lot of change today compared to a quarter ago. And so I would say, we're continuing to operate like we have been. I would say, as we look into fiscal '17, if I were to make a comment about the economy that maybe did feel a little different, I would say today compared to, let's call it, 6 months ago, it does feel like there's a bit more uncertainty. When you think about the -- we do -- we have seen some ups and downs in employment, no doubt about that. We've seen the European issues, we've seen changes from the Department of Labor in terms of minimum wage and overtime that can have a pausing effect on our customers. We've got the election coming up. It does feel like there's a little bit more uncertainty than there was 6 months ago. And that's likely bleeding into the bottom end of our guidance range.

headline: Cintas Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right, thanks, that's helpful. I mean, you talked kind of piecemeal as we've gone through Q&A with regard to say, branding and what quarters that may hit more. Could you speak to, I don't know if you mentioned the quarter with the the extra or the 1 l
componenttext: All right, thanks, that's helpful. I mean, you talked kind of piecemeal as we've gone through Q&A with regard to say, branding and what quarters that may hit more. Could you speak to, I don't know if you mentioned the quarter with the the extra or the 1 less day. But on a quarterly basis, top to bottom, when might we expect some of the ebbs and flows, I guess I'm thinking more on expense and how it will impact the margin? But just how we move through the year? Is there anything worth pointing out that will be a big factor just on a sequential basis as we move through the year? Thanks.

headline: Cintas Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. I would say a couple of things, Scott. Paul talked about a tax rate of 36.7%. That's a little bit higher than last year. But lower than our, maybe, our longer-term. I would expect that we're going to see a slightly lower tax rate in the first quarte
componenttext: Sure. I would say a couple of things, Scott. Paul talked about a tax rate of 36.7%. That's a little bit higher than last year. But lower than our, maybe, our longer-term. I would expect that we're going to see a slightly lower tax rate in the first quarter followed by something closer to what we've typically guided toward in that 37% range in the last three quarters. So that's maybe one point. From a Ready for the Workday campaign standpoint, I would say that it is going to -- the bulk of it is going to be in the second and third quarters. From an SAP standpoint, we talked earlier about that will be back end loaded. So we will have some costs in the first half of the year. But we turn on the depreciation and we turn on the licensing expenses in the second half of the year. So we will see -- we'll see a little bit more pressure in that back half from that standpoint. And as far as calling things out, I think, maybe the other thing that I might call out is the first quarter, as Paul mentioned, would have a little bit heavier, from a First Aid standpoint, ZEE implementation and integration costs. But from a quarter-to-quarter basis, I don't know that I'd have a much more to share than that.

headline: Cintas Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: I can't recall, Scott, if we mentioned, that the third quarter is the quarter with the one less workday.
componenttext: I can't recall, Scott, if we mentioned, that the third quarter is the quarter with the one less workday.

headline: Cintas Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Adrian Paz on for George Tong. I just wanted to get little more color on M&A. I know for a long time, since you didn't do any acquisitions in recent quarters, we've seen a pretty a bit, yes, in recent quarters we've seen a pretty big uptick in acq
componenttext: This is Adrian Paz on for George Tong. I just wanted to get little more color on M&A. I know for a long time, since you didn't do any acquisitions in recent quarters, we've seen a pretty a bit, yes, in recent quarters we've seen a pretty big uptick in acquisition activity. I mean, is -- are you seeing better valuations out there? And is there any segment that you're targeting growth in through M&A?

headline: Cintas Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we -- I would say that as far as M&A goes, it really is opportunistic. So when the opportunities become available, we need to be ready to take advantage of those. And we were opportunistic in fiscal '16, certainly. We would look for acquisitions in
componenttext: Well, we -- I would say that as far as M&A goes, it really is opportunistic. So when the opportunities become available, we need to be ready to take advantage of those. And we were opportunistic in fiscal '16, certainly. We would look for acquisitions in our Rental business, in our First Aid and Safety business, and our Fire businesses, primarily. We love tuck-in acquisitions, they are very accretive. And we'll continue to look aggressively for those kind of opportunities provided there at the right value. We might look for bigger opportunities in any of those businesses, again, as long as they provide long-term value for us and at the right valuation.

headline: Cintas Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: And also, can you provide an update on Canadian operations? I know they had been experiencing some headwinds a few quarters back with the currency. Have those -- I guess, have operations there stabilized? And are they, I guess, resuming growth?
componenttext: And also, can you provide an update on Canadian operations? I know they had been experiencing some headwinds a few quarters back with the currency. Have those -- I guess, have operations there stabilized? And are they, I guess, resuming growth?

headline: Cintas Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I would say that the performance of the business there hasn't necessarily been affected by the currency exchange rate. Our business continues to perform well. But we have seen less volatility in that Canadian exchange rate. I think the negative impa
componenttext: Well, I would say that the performance of the business there hasn't necessarily been affected by the currency exchange rate. Our business continues to perform well. But we have seen less volatility in that Canadian exchange rate. I think the negative impact to the top line was 30 basis points. So we're still seeing a little bit of negative. But generally speaking, the business continues to perform well.

headline: Cintas Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll take our next question from Andrew Steinerman with JPMorgan.

headline: Cintas Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016

componenttext: Could you just tell us what share count we should use for the first quarter based on the share buyback that was done already? And does your guidance assume any further share buyback?

headline: Cintas Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Andrew, it's Paul. The guidance does not assume any further share buyback. Maybe just to sync up, I don't know if you noticed, but with the earnings release, we have an income statement that we enclosed and there's a supplemental schedule in there that ha
componenttext: Andrew, it's Paul. The guidance does not assume any further share buyback. Maybe just to sync up, I don't know if you noticed, but with the earnings release, we have an income statement that we enclosed and there's a supplemental schedule in there that has a computation of diluted EPS. And if you look at that for the 12 months ended May 31, 2016, you'll see our computation there for the current year when we start off with income from continuing ops, we reduce it and it's about 1.6% reduction to allocate income to this participating securities. And then we divided that number by 110 million diluted shares outstanding. And so in fiscal '17, for our modeling, we're going to use about that same $110 million -- not $100 million, 110 million shares rather, for computation of fiscal '17 EPS so your '17 number, reduce it for the income for the participating securities and look at 110 million shares.

headline: Cintas Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016

headline: Cintas Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: I know you don't guide to margin growth. But if I think through the $30 million to $35 million of incremental SAP expense, and I think about what the implied -- what might -- what the implied operating margin growth is this year, say, at the midpoint, may
componenttext: I know you don't guide to margin growth. But if I think through the $30 million to $35 million of incremental SAP expense, and I think about what the implied -- what might -- what the implied operating margin growth is this year, say, at the midpoint, maybe down 40 basis points, if I add back the SAP, I'm looking at maybe 20-ish, that's still a step down from what you did last year even at the midpoint. Is that just conservatism? Or can you maybe help me bridge through how should we think about that? Thanks.

headline: Cintas Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, our total incremental margins for fiscal '16 for the company was -- were about 20%. Rental was certainly higher. Rental was more like 28%. We have talked about, historically, that that incremental margin, we want that incremental margin to be in the
componenttext: Well, our total incremental margins for fiscal '16 for the company was -- were about 20%. Rental was certainly higher. Rental was more like 28%. We have talked about, historically, that that incremental margin, we want that incremental margin to be in the 20% to 30% range. If we are higher than that for sustained periods of time, we worry that we're not investing enough. And I would tell you that as we look into '17, excluding the SAP impact, we're about in that same range, maybe a little bit on the lower side because of the negative oil and gas impact, because of the negative workday impact. But generally speaking, we think there are good incremental margins. And at the top end of the guidance, even with the SAP impact, even with the oil and gas, even with the extra workday, there's a slight operating margin improvement.

headline: Cintas Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And I remember last time, you said you won't be sitting idly watching the $30 million to $35 million flow down to the bottom-line. How do you feel about this today 4 months later?
componenttext: Got it. And I remember last time, you said you won't be sitting idly watching the $30 million to $35 million flow down to the bottom-line. How do you feel about this today 4 months later?

headline: Cintas Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I would like to think that the guidance that we've provided is an indication that that's exactly what we've done and that is not sit around idly waiting for $30 million to $35 million to hit. But instead, we're continuing to run the business, execut
componenttext: Well, I would like to think that the guidance that we've provided is an indication that that's exactly what we've done and that is not sit around idly waiting for $30 million to $35 million to hit. But instead, we're continuing to run the business, execute very, very well, improve where we can and come up with very good results. And we feel good about the business. I think that guidance would tell you that we feel good going into fiscal '17. And our partners still are executing at very, very high levels.
